150651238.review:
Pros:

Great dialogue, great story, great background music. Characters were really well-written and the travelling back in time element of this game was really fun to play around with. I liked the detail put into the world-building, and the suspense felt behind every decision-making moment. I felt like this game was very nostalgic while I was playing it. I think this game pulled this off well with its introspective approach i.e. the diary kept by Max and the photographs taken. You felt attached to the characters in the game. I also liked that you could compare the choices you made with your friends and with everyone else who's played the game after every chapter. The story was well thought out and it put you in a great dilemma when deciding which characters were trustworthy. The music was also really fitting and added to the game's teenage American 2000/2010's feel.

Cons:

I'd say the puny amount of endings that this game offers can be a downside if you were expecting that your choices would dramatically change the ending of the game. Though to me it was still worth it.
I also encountered a couple of glitches in the game as well but they weren't too bad.

150464694.review:
I never do this, but I loved this game - right until I didn't. Spoilers ahead.








In principle, this game is brilliant. I enjoyed the characters, the time travel mechanic is cleverly done, and the puzzle elements were compelling without becoming frustrating. I would have had no hesitation in recommending this game, and in fact I did and offered to buy it for a friend. 

Right up until the end.

To me, the whole point of this game was to explore concepts like consequences and agency as experienced in the life of a sympathetic and compelling character. I went into the game with the idea that it was a "choices matter" game, and I went in sincerely believing that - with the exception of a few somewhat jarring moments when the plot seemed to be on rails - I would get a ton of replay value from going back and exploring how the story played out if I made other decisions. I was looking forward to seeing how the decisions I had made (and sometimes agonized over) would impact the ending, so it was pretty profoundly disappointing to learn that, seemingly, they didn't. Instead, I was faced with a binary choice of what I will cryptically refer to as Destiny or Destruction, and both options were depressing. 

This game is beautiful and brilliant. Hats off to the developers for creating it, and I have every intention of looking into their other games. Unfortunately, I feel like there was a huge opportunity missed here, and that makes me sad.

150302540.review:
[h3] Played this game on console and downloaded here just so I can make this review, so obviously: I'll only talk about the pros of this game (I'm late I know) [/h3]

Most of the times I found kinda - strange - how Life is Strange manages to continue being so up to date and interesting to so many people, yet, if we think about our current capitalist reality, in which our social relationships are becoming more and more liquid and - with the internet ascension - our lives have become faster and emptier, it makes sense all the interest this games awakens on us, specially by working with the most limited and hard to control resource nowadays: the time; and none of us want to regret something 

LIS plays with a common fantasy, of being able to manipulate such an absolute resource, but it is not limited to just a superpower game and entertainment, on the contrary, since it is such a complex Choices Matter game, the franchise grows even more in admiration for making us think about our own lives while playing, because in it: every.choice.matters.

Developing a dense and complete plot that desires to be as real as possible while using time manipulation as a narrative engine is not an easy task, but LIS manages it flawlessly. Watching the develop of Chloe and Max's story evokes a whirlwind of feelings; pain, sadness, joy and sympathy are the most recurrent, at least in my experience. And it's important to say that the franchise goes beyond the two girls, and also delights and touch the player several times by diving intensely into the complicated life of each citizen of Arcadia Bay that we can interact with, each one more complex and interesting than the other, but above all: you feel like you are interacting with a real person, like everything in LIS will always feel so real.

The environment is so highly detailed, all things were thought out and reckoned down to the smallest details and everything here has a reason and a meaning, nothing is "by chance" or just for style points. Speaking of style, the game, even without having the biggest budget, knows how to perfectly convey the feeling and ambiance needed for each scene, and the cartoonish touches, the painting, the soundtrack and lighting will all bring the intimate and cozy feeling impeccably. But not only that, the game will also use the same elements (and many others) to bring us pain and fear when necessary, and as ironic as it may seem, time will fly right before your eyes while playing, and you'll catch yourself playing a 2-hour episode without even feeling it, and, in fact, this may be the only thing you won't feel here.

Talking about such a complete and complex masterpiece like this would take me tons of pages, space I don't have here, but don't fret, nothing is worthier than try it out to make your own conclusions when we're talking about Life is Strange. It'll literally be impossible for you to waste your time playing it, and be prepared tho.

Ready for the mosh pit, shaka bra?

150224466.review:
Cannot recommend to people like me. If you're misanthropic or just don't care for teeny angst and self-promoters, it's likely just gonna be taxing for your "social battery".
Characters are mostly well designed and believable, if you restrain your expectations to giving everybody under the age of 25 or so in the game about as much credit as you'd probably give children throwing tantrums, teenagers experiencing their first rushes and overdramatic or overportraited personalities being must have trope characters so minorities within minorities can identify themselves with somebody.
Adult characters in the game, on the other hand, are actually well designed. Would have been a lot better without the pretentiousness and the catering to young (american) audiences.
The main reason that I dislike the game though is the illusion of choice in regards to the absolute ending of the game.
Spoiler (somewhat):
There's only really 2 ending cinematics and they (didn't test, but logically can't deduce any other results) don't differ at all, no matter the playthrough choices.
The way up to the end does differ though and character interactions do change noticeably enough.
Consistency within chosen paths and overall storytelling continuity does seem to be well done and without bugs though.
If you're an emotional, less critical person, I can see some merit to experiencing the story.
The game doesn't step out of character throughout, so the quality it promises in episode 1 will be the same that it delivers in episode 5.
If I had to rate my experience, I'd give the game a 4/10. If I had to rate the overall products quality, I'd probably give it a 7.5/10.

149734977.review:
It's been years and Max's lack of mouth animations on the Two Whales cutscene in episode 5 hasn't been fixed, well, with the remaster out it probably never will, but personally, if you dont care about the look of the game (although it is mostly cutscenes) just get this version, I personally like the look of it more.
The rewind mechanic is one of my favourite game mechanics in "movie games", in any other story driven game this would be considered "save-scumming" but Life is Strange actively encourages you to rewind and see all possible outcomes and pick the one you find most favourable, while not shying away from showing you the consequences of Max abusing her powers, though I wish it had more of a punishing system gameplay-wise like a cooldown if you rewind too many times in a row, though i suppose it does have a limit on how far back you can go in any given scene
Story-wise, im not gonna go on a tirade on how "cheesy" or "awkward" the dialogue is, this game is about 18 year olds in 2013, I was an 18 year old in 2013, me and my friends also said hella lame things like the characters in LiS, though I do feel like you can tell by the usage of slang at times that it wasn't written by a native english speaker (the over-use of the word Busted, which at times is contextually incorrect is the biggest example)
The development of Max and Chloe's friendship and it's culmination on the final lighthouse scene is what made me realise i was in love with my best friend and we've been a couple since 2015, so thanks DONTNOD for making us g4y

149715620.review: One of the best story driven, narrative games I've ever played. The characters are phenomenally created, producing feelings of both empathy and sympathy whilst progressing through the story line and seeing firsthand how your actions have an effect on various characters. The setting is also amazingly done, with Arcadia Bay & Blackwell Academy being both memorable and enjoyable to navigate/explore whilst building relations with fellow classmates and strangers alike. The VA/dialogue is amazing for all of the characters (although rather corny at times) as it truly makes you feel like you're back at Highschool with the cliquey feel, along with the not so rudimentary bullying that occurs. The SFX is great, the cinematics were nicely shot (although dated in texture quality) and the music was absolutely spot on. One of the reasons I enjoyed this game so much was the musical score, and not only were the OST's great, but how they were incorporated into the game and cinematics created many goosies! Now apart from the character design, the gameplay/story stole the show. The ability to build relations the way you see fit using Max's supernatural powers was incredibly fun. Being somewhat of a "perfectionist" when it comes to RPG's and story/narrative driven games, being able to explore the various dialogue options and seeing how they effect the future story choices by using Max's ability was soooo good. No more saving prior to a big story pathway decision, or even googling the results of said actions just to make sure you don't completely bottle everything, being able to use Max's supernatural ability to explore the various options was truly enjoyable, and quite often comedic as well. I personally don't get emotionally attached to games that often,  but Life is Strange did a great job at tugging at the heart strings. Personally, what enabled this was remembering most of the characters names and personalities, or even the notable features of the game's setting or places of interest as a result of how well these aspects of the game were created. The only notable drawback was the rather poor visual quality of the textures and the facial animations/lip syncing, but the game was released in 2013 so there is some slack to be given. Definitely a must play, especially being such an original game - 9.5/10

149486080.review:
A dramatic twist simulator with optional plot holes to discover (seriously, why can't you use any of the optional photos you take?) There's a significant amount of plot dedicated to solving the mystery of a disappeared girl, which involves a lot of the protagonist retracing the victim's steps--up to, and very nearly including, her final ones.

Ultimately, though, it's a whirlwind faux-mance about an emotionally stunted hipster and her blue-haired manic pixie dream girl, straight out of a quote from Caitlyn Siehl:

"Do not fall in love with people like me.
I will take you museums, and parks, and monuments, and kiss you in every beautiful place, so that you can never go back to them without tasting me like blood in your mouth.
I will destroy you in the most beautiful way possible. And when I leave you will finally understand, why storms are named after people."

In the end, you have to decide whether Topical Storm Chloe is worth weathering. Personally, the Price was too much for me, but maybe that's just because I'm a horrible person. I don't regret saving Arcadia.

149450153.review:
[h2] in one word: awesome [/h2] 
In two words Awesome and Awesome.
Emotional, well written, interesting characters and places, unexpected twists, meaningful choices.

I think this is one of the greatest [strike] games [/strike] experiences i have ever had. It has to be your cup of tea, but if it is.... you will love it. And you will hate it bcs its also the most emotional thing i have ever done outside of real life. You. Will. Cry.  If you can go through this with a blank stare and feeling nothing.. apply for a job at twitter. Might just be able to keep it together there.. Rumours have it mr spock played this and cried.

Joking aside, what can i say without spoilers? 
You are Max(ine) Caulfield. a somewhat introvert 17 year old girl going to college, back in the town she grew up in and left 5 years ago. Meet up with old friends, make new ones, see familiar places, experience what has changed and what has stayed the same.. Unravel a mystery, maybe find love. You make the choices and deal with any consequences, good or bad. Or good ànd bad. You discover more about Max' past and shape her future. Tough choices an difficult dilemmas. Joy and fear, melancholy and despair. every human emotion is in here.
You will get drawn in and feel with the characters'emotions, feel their joy and grief make sure you have at least 25 hours available in one week bcs its worth playing this without large gaps.I played it in 18 hrs over 2 or 3 days. Oh and i needed about a week or 2 before i was emotionally recovered. Might want to keep some time for that lol. Did i mention you will cry? bcs you will.  

In the end it was a cathartic  experience for me. As Max came to terms with her past, made something of her present and worked towards making the future... i healed stuff from my past, felt better about the present and felt inspired to do more with my future.
Hmm.. maybe im over-emotionalising it as i am very sensitive to touching stories.. But play it. Its awesome. Might look for the remastered one...i hear it looks better.

Its most certainly worth your 20 euro-equivalent money units imho just for how brilliant the story sucks you in and makes you care, but you can get it on sale ofc. Looks like the first ep is available for free which is awesome... try it! And tell them [strike] steph [/strike] Kira sent ya (insider joke, you'll get it when you play the third game, which you likely will if you like this one.)

148880198.review:
After trying to get into this game multiple times throughout the years, I finally managed to get into it enough to beat it.

I wish that Steam let us review games as "neutral" because that is how I feel about LiS. It's not the best game ever, but it's not the worst either. It seems to sit somewhere in that weird "Hey, if you want to spend 15 or so hours stuck with annoying, mean, bullying young adults and their drama, be my guest!".

I struggle to understand why this game has such good reviews when its pacing is all over the place, the gameplay is fairly standard, the graphics are stylized but absolutely stacked with bad animation; most of the characters even though well written for the most part, often end up being an absolute joy-kill to be around and as a game that  self describes itself as a "choice matters" game, in reality and actuality nothing you do in the game matters until the very last 5 or so minutes of the game.

I could go on about many issues I've had here with this game, but I will just get the one that irked me the most out of the way - I hated almost every single moment I had to spend with Chloe - I dislike her no matter when she is, how she is, why she is, she is a bad friend, she is manipulative, she is mean to everyone and you will be stuck dealing with her nonsense for most of the game, right to the very end. I do not think I have ever had a displeasure of being forced to "care" for a character in a video game as much as I did here. I really, really dislike her xD

So yeah, overall the vibe was kinda cool but screw Chloe and her BS drama and crap. Would not ever want to play this game ever again. 

On paper, this game is perfect for me. In practice, I was frustrated and often annoyed by being forced to revolve an entire game around Chloe.

I felt bad for Max for having to deal with her. She was smart to not get in touch with her for 5 years and it should have stayed that way. 

Now try to guess my choice at the very end of the game. 

Lol.

148769254.review:
[b] **Trigger Warning: The following review contains discussions of sensitive and potentially triggering content, including suicide, self-harm, sexual assault, bullying, and other mature themes.** [/b]

"LIFE IS STRANGE" - A Somber Reflection

"LIFE IS STRANGE," a narrative adventure game developed by Dontnod Entertainment, is a perplexing and profound journey into the lives of its characters and the raw, uncomfortable realities they face. This game, however, is not for the faint of heart, as it delves deeply into themes that often remain hidden beneath the surface of everyday life.

From the very start, "LIFE IS STRANGE" pulls no punches. It tackles issues such as bullying, suicide, self-harm, sexual assault, and more, forcing players to confront the harshness of these themes. This is where the game's strength lies, in its unflinching portrayal of the real struggles and turmoil faced by its teenage protagonists. It doesn't sugarcoat the challenges they experience, and it encourages players to empathize with their plights.

Yet, this is also where "LIFE IS STRANGE" becomes a double-edged sword. Its unrelenting dive into these dark waters occasionally feels overwhelming and unnecessarily grim, almost as if it's attempting to outdo itself in depicting trauma. It's a stark reminder that life, indeed, is not always kind, but at times, it feels gratuitous in its attempts to convey this message.

What sets "LIFE IS STRANGE" apart is its emotionally charged storytelling. The characters are well-developed, and the relationships they form are both relatable and heart-wrenching. The game's focus on choice and consequence adds depth to the narrative, as each decision resonates with the player on a personal level, making them ponder the ethical and emotional consequences of their actions.

The game's various endings, however, are where the narrative takes a strange, almost nonsensical turn. Without delving into spoilers, it can be argued that these endings feel disconnected from the weight of the rest of the story. They left many players feeling that the emotional investment they had made in the characters had been undermined by a conclusion that didn't quite fit.

Nevertheless, where "LIFE IS STRANGE" undoubtedly excels is its soundtrack. The music, often melancholic and reflective, perfectly complements the game's themes and adds a layer of emotional depth that resonates long after the credits roll. In this aspect, the game truly shines, making its players feel the depths of its characters' sorrow and struggles.

In summary, "LIFE IS STRANGE" is a well-written, tragic drama that unapologetically explores the most challenging aspects of life for young adults. It has its moments of brilliance, its moments of utter chaos and absurdity, and its moments of sheer, unflinching reality. It may not be a game for everyone due to its heavy themes, and the conclusion may leave players feeling divided, but it's a memorable experience that has successfully captured the attention of its audience and evoked emotions that are impossible to forget.

148249186.review:
"Life is Strange" is a popular episodic video game series developed by Dontnod Entertainment. While the game has received critical acclaim and has a dedicated fan base, it's not without its criticisms and flaws. Here are some common criticisms of the series:

1. Pacing Issues: Some players have found the pacing of the game to be slow, particularly in the first episode. The game's focus on character development and story can sometimes lead to a lack of action, which may not appeal to all players.

2. Dialogue and Writing: The dialogue in "Life is Strange" can be hit or miss. Some players feel that the teenage characters use unrealistic or cringe-worthy language and expressions, and the writing occasionally veers into melodrama.

3. Lip Syncing and Animation: The lip-syncing in the game has been criticized for not always syncing well with the dialogue. The animation can also feel stiff or awkward at times.

4. Binary Choices: "Life is Strange" is known for its branching narrative and choices that affect the story's outcome. However, some players have criticized the binary nature of these choices, where it can feel like you're choosing between two extreme options rather than making nuanced decisions.

5. Inconsistent Voice Acting: While the game features a strong voice cast, some players have found the quality of voice acting to be uneven, with some characters' performances standing out more than others.

6. Plot Holes and Unexplained Mysteries: The game introduces several supernatural elements and mysteries, but not all of these are satisfactorily explained, leading to frustration among players who were hoping for more closure.

7. Limited Gameplay: "Life is Strange" is primarily an interactive drama, and some players may find the gameplay elements to be limited or lacking in complexity. There's a stronger focus on storytelling than traditional gameplay.

8. Technical Issues: Some players have reported technical issues such as bugs and crashes, which can affect the overall experience.

9. Some Controversial Themes: The game tackles various serious and controversial themes such as mental health, bullying, and suicide. While some players appreciate the game's willingness to address these issues, others may find it heavy-handed or mishandled.

10. Art Style: The game's art style, which features hand-painted textures and a somewhat surreal aesthetic, is a point of contention. Some players love it, while others find it off-putting.

It's important to note that these criticisms are subjective, and many players and critics have praised "Life is Strange" for its engaging narrative, well-developed characters, and unique approach to storytelling. Whether you enjoy the game or not largely depends on your personal preferences and how much you connect with its characters and themes.

148235408.review:
Take the gameplay of The Walking Dead, but with choices actually impacting further developments. Take the Butterfly Effect and make the story even more unpredictable. Take the tragedy of any given drama and mix everything. What you get is this game.

Characters can be a bit inconsistent and change attitudes too fast, but they invoke emotions, good or bad (you can't (dis)like practically anyone). You can predict many twists, but some will catch you unprepared. Episodes 3 & 4 had most powerful delivery and 5 seemed forced in a way, but ultimately made sense in the final decision you have to make.

Very much recommended.

I finished the first chapter in 3 hours, playing fairly completionist. Others may find they go through it quicker, but I enjoyed the dialogue and sometimes hidden options you would otherwise not have known if you didn't explore every edge.

Graphically, it's a pretty style, but I had major artifacting around objects with "bloom" effects on them, as well as the edges of focused versus blurred areas (so if a face was in focus, the transition from there to the blurred area would be jagged and with artifacts). That said, I enjoyed the cinematography and creative shots and angles the designers put in. As a photographer, the focus on creative angles and use of foreground, background, and the focus on beauty and stylized detail really enhanced the experience.

    There are many things to point out when discussing what makes playing this game such a memorable experience. Is it the fact, that one completely overlooks the simplicity of graphics in favor of the richness of the story the game presents? Or is it a psychological precision with which the developers carved out their characters? Or is it the world of Arcadia Bay which practically breathes with life, inviting the player in every of its corners? No doubt: deep ethical and philosophical dilemmas, grounded in the cutting edge scientific observations of our times, which this game presents, MUST be the key factor in making this game such an unbelievable experience for those, who invest their time and attention into playing "Life is Strange".

Wow, where do I even start with Life is Strange? This game is a rollercoaster of emotions and I’m here for it! Max and Chloe are the heart and soul of this journey. They’re not your typical game characters - they’re real, flawed, and super relatable.

147589727.review:
I have played this before, I have the physical edition for PS4, and I loved playing it back then.

It’s not perfect however. The dialogue and scripting can be awkward, the pacing could be better, and sometimes the choices you can make don’t matter that much. And it’s all set within an American setting that is obviously made people by outside of the United States. But I didn’t really care about the game's issues because I really enjoyed replaying Life Is Strange all over again.

The story and characters all have this awkward and idiosyncratic charm reminiscent of Twin Peaks, but it is also really interesting and sometimes absorbing. The rewind mechanic makes for compelling moments that will surprise many players, and it is really unique how most choices can be rewound so you can see the other immediate outcomes of your choices. It’s also just really fun to rewind time and play around with the dialogue and characters. 

I also really liked the performances of the two leads. Ashley Birch’s performance as Chloe is definitely a highlight but Hannah Telle’s performance as Max is also worth mentioning. The latter’s character and the pairing of her interest in photography with her time travel abilities is just a really good match in general.

So I do recommend Life Is Strange. Experiencing it again after not playing it in several years was really worth it. It’s probably the closest I could have gotten to playing it again for the first time.

-----------------------------------------

One last thing to say is that there are two versions of Life Is Strange. This version (the original) was made with a low budget but it had a photographic art style. The remaster was done by Deck Nine, not DONTNOD – the original developers. 

Faces, facial animations, hair, and some environments look better but some aspects are definitely uneven and the remaster looks darker overall. Not that Deck Nine did a bad job but there are several reasons why the original version of Life Is Strange might be worth picking up over the remaster:
[list]
[*]The original game is cheaper, especially on sale.

[*]You can get the first episode for [u]free[/u]. Essentially you get a full episode as a demo.

[*]It’s the original game that DONTNOD had released during 2015. Some people might see the value in that.
[/list]
The remaster is also reported to have several issues even after recent patches. But the original is also somewhat buggy as well. I have had at least one or two bugs per episode. Most are nothing serious but I did get stuck in the environment twice however. 

The original game still has its low budget but stylistic charm and has its own reasons why someone would pick it over the remaster. But to be honest you could go either way here. Whether you want something that is true to the original or the remastered version you’re going to be experiencing the same great story and rewind mechanic.

This was my first playthrough of the game and now that I've completed the game 100% with all achievements I wanted to review it.

This game is my boyfriend's favourite to date and I never understood why until he encouraged me to play it, with him watching as I did. I found this game to be incredibly beautiful, complicated and inspiring.

My experience with this game was fantastic, I laughed, I cried (more like bawled my eyes out) and it really made me think about the world, the consequences of my actions and it truly changed my perspective on almost every character from episode 1 to episode 5.

I never knew how much a game could impact my life until I played this one and everything is written so beautifully that I was so invested in every little detail, every piece of dialogue, every event and that's very difficult to do in a game, especially a game where you need to pay attention because every choice you make, no matter how small can impact the whole experience.

I recommend this game to anyone who has had thoughts of playing and anyone who wants to enjoy a new type of gaming experience compared to modern style games like Valorant, Overwatch etc. It's truly an amazing play. Hats off to the creators.

La mecánica central del juego, la capacidad de Max para retroceder en el tiempo y cambiar sus decisiones, agrega una dimensión única a la toma de decisiones en el juego. 146977422.review:
Life Is Strange is a blend of some of my favorite video game genres. I am a huge fan of the Telltale games and I love games with some kind of time manipulation mechanic. I enjoyed the game and I looked forward to playing it, but the plethora of issues it has in both story and game play dimensions leaves me to just barely recommend this title.

This game has a lot of great qualities bogged down by not-so-great qualities. The voice acting is stellar, but the writing is really awkward. "Wowsers." The game does a great job of creating a cinematic atmosphere, except when for some weird reason the character's lips stop moving or the voice actor was told to shout their lines because they're at a loud party... except it's a scene in the bathroom where the music is a lot quieter. The time control mechanic is nicely implemented, except that the "shift" to rewind faster button hardly seems to do anything at times. Some of the dialog choices are interesting, but they're often so nondescript that you can't even tell what you're opting to say. There are just a lot of issues with this game getting in the way of things.

Overall, my main critique comes down to the pacing. I almost stopped playing after episode 1 but after seeing comments about things getting more interesting, I gave it a shot. To its credit, things did get more interesting. However the slow pacing issues it had from the start never went away. The game is constantly trying to set a mood with ambient lighting, music, and emotional voice acting, but it doesn't have the writing to back it up. Some of the scenes are too long and lack substance or significance. I found myself bored quite often. It's tedious to listen to all the dialog and content in the game but if you skip through everything it kind of defeats the purpose of what I'm playing. It's a dilemma I found myself in time and time again.

The story is somewhat interesting in that it at least adds layers the more you play, but at the end of the day I found that Life Is Strange more often tells you how to feel instead of letting the game play and writing speak for itself.

Verdict: MODERATELY GOOD

146850345.review:
Life is Strange was a fantastic game from start to finish. It really hooked me in with it's time travel mechanics, but then made me stay for it's gut-wrenching yet euphoric story. They also delved way deeper into it's time travel lore than I was initially expecting- something I really appreciated as a sci-fi fan. Much more substance than your cliche "oh no! don't cause a paradox!" scene you get from lots of traditional media these days.

Many movies, TV shows, or games, are able to make me feel happy or feel sad, sometimes to the point of laughing out loud or crying, but very few are able to make me feel other emotions just as strongly. This game has some moments of visceral disgust, as well as total catharsis. It's choice-based mechanics can even make your experience existential. 

Graphics are usually the last thing I care about in video games, but despite it being eight and a half years old, the graphics hold up and it's a pretty game to walk through. Seeing realistic human expression and emotion adds so much depth to the emotions you feel as the player.

The only downside is there isn't much gameplay other than walking around and making dialogue choices. The very last chapter introduces some hide-and-seek gameplay mechanics, but it's more tedious than it is fun, imo, mostly due to how slow you have to sneak around. The atmosphere is crazy good at that part, though, which more than makes up for it.

My last point is just that the achievements seem a bit obtuse. There's 50 of them and they all involve finding a secret location for taking a picture. Sometimes you have to go through entire dialogue interactions, rewind to get the correct dialogue options, and only *then* are you able to take one of these secret pictures. I ended up only getting about 12 on my normal playthrough and it also felt somewhat tedious to go back and get the rest of them using a guide. In their defense, after beating the game, you unlock a "collectable mode" that lets you get collectables without affecting your choices, and you can also skip to various different points within each chapter to essentially skip right to a photo. Despite this, there are many chapters where you have to sit through a long opening, or go through various plot point cutscenes and dialogues until you get to the point you can take the picture. My advice would be to look for a spoiler-free achievement guide you can follow during your initial playthrough.

Achievement-hunting aside, I truly believe that this game is an absolute must-play, for anyone who likes or doesn't like video games. It's a beautiful story that almost anyone will be able to relate to. If you like sci-fi or happen to be from the state of Oregon, that also adds a cherry on top!

Also, bae before bay 4 lyfe.

Life is strange is truly one of the best narrative, choice-based games out there. The characters are well-built and the story itself is great. I mean, yeah it kinda sucks that at the end, only a single choice matters. Imagine doing all kind of things and they all turn out to be worthless. Frustrating, ain't it? But apart from all of this, the best thing is*Drum rolls please*: The music. Both the OSTs and songs are just incredible. 146090784.review:
As a fan of choice-based narrative adventure games, I really wanted to like this game. But, I just can't take it seriously. The writing is both annoying and laughable and the characters are either exaggerated stereotypes or thoroughly unlikable people. I only started to enjoy the game when I stopped trying to take it seriously and embraced how ridiculous it all was.
Chloe and Max are supposed to be likable and relatable characters (I think?) and yet I can't relate to either of them. That would be perfectly fine if, Chloe especially, weren't such a horrible person that the game somehow expects you to care for. While it's great that many people have felt a deep connection to this game, I certainly could not, and that's why I hesitate to recommend it.

146050609.review:
[h3]  READ HERE, if you're new to the franchise  [/h3]
This is my objective rating of all games (sort of)

1. Life is Strange (2015)
Simply the best, though not my personal favourite this one sets the bar pretty damn high. It has great characters and location settings. A rich story and the protagonist "gift" does not feel as confined as later edition in the franchiche. 

2. Life is Strange 2 (2018-2019)
My favourite, I enjoyed the episodic release however it was to long in between. 1-2 weeks gap would have been fine. It got an feel of exploration and adventure, a great road trip. I wish our main protagonists would meet up with the ones from LiS1 at some point in the franchise. Protagonist "gift" was limited to certain moment and that I did not like that concept. There must certainly been way to write around it, giving us some leeway.

*The Awesome Adventures of Captain Spirit* (2018)
A side story, but it's really good! Very short, I don't want to spoil anything, but if you want the perfect experience, PLAY this after LiS2 first episode.

3. Life is Strange: Before the storm (2017)
PLAY this before LiS1 if you have the possibility. It went deeper into some characters background and really add to the lore. Certain parts really hit the high notes. It's a prologue to LiS1

*Life is Strange: Before the storm - Farewell (2018) 
As the main game, this bonus episode gives some insight in the protagonist background in LiS1, especially on their starting points. A short but cute edition. 

4. Life is Strange: True Colors (2021)
A nice setting, and got the looks. Interesting characters, but the game is way to short. I felt it had something going on, and then just ended. 

-Life is Strange: True Colors Steph's story (dlc) is exclusive to Deluxe upgrade and Ultimate. I think this is a really bad idea. I won't buy it, unless it will be released as buyable dlc, [u] DO NOT [/u] promote this kind of business model my dear LiS fans. I am fine with deluxe and ultimate regarding to cosmetics, earlier release, but not exclusive stories.

5. Tell me why (2020)
Standalone, yet still worth the experience. Quite boring characters, but the game is artistically interesting. It has its moment here and there. Not LiS, but has the same vibes.

*I haven't bought the remastered edition because I've already got an great experience of these games when they were first released. As I understand nothing important was really added to their ReM either?  I would rather see longer games, more customization, less restrictions and perhaps make mini ingames ranked? I would like to have an connection ingame to other players in some way other than gamechoice summary. Maybe use your phone ingame to contact other players on route? Who knows..

145691471.review:
A great premise, truly bends the mind as one goes down the rabbit hole. Full of easter eggs, clues and quarks. Implementing time travel makes the "choices matter" experience a lot more fun but doesn't remove the edge of the mystery and suspense which builds perfectly throughout each part.

I feel like the developers captured a lot of what may be perceived as "archetypal" drama/relations which mirror and frame recent past and current modern American social issues rather well. Although the particular "type" of drama which forms the basis for the story line is not something I generally enjoy, it was well written and executed. 

The game-play mechanics are nice, simple and stress-free. The warping of space/time puzzle solving process is still exciting to think about even after playing through the game and feels very fresh from other titles which attempt similar processes but with very different overall game-play mechanics and story-goals.

The character dialogue felt a little stiff at times, but funnily seemed to coincide with some stiff character visual animations...maybe needs some smoothing out somewhere.

The dark and twisted path the story cuts is very heart wrenching and at times, believable to the point where one wonders if it is based on true events (in game disclaimer states otherwise). I find this to be good storytelling though, not a negative! 

It only took a couple days to complete 1 play-through but this was only due to the compulsion to stay up way to late to play through the last two chapters, once it hooks you, it's hard to set it down until you know how it ends....and there are end(s)!! If you are more patient, there is a lot more to get out of it, as I didn't completely take the time to do some of the side stuff.

In all, a fantastic, magical, very emotional, twisted and chilling game. Will play again. Can't wait to play the next. Good job! This is the future of gaming.

145390810.review:
Highlight: This terrible game became popular and "good" only because of lesbians. 

Cut short: gameplay is bad and the writing is worse. 
Characters are horrible and the dialogue makes me cry. 
It's a sh!t game  which only works because people have low expectations. I am talking about Sonic fan levels of low expectations.
 
The only choice that matters is at the very end. Maxes power is contrived bullish!t it simply doesn't make any sense… But that is only the tip of the iceberg. It breaks its own rules, invents stakes when there are none, Max suddenly gets enhanced powers due to an emotional moment. 

Textures, animation, lyp syncing and models are bad. Mind you this game was funded by Square Enix. 

The "Protagonist" of this game is Chloe, she is a nihilist, hedonist, immoral, d3g3n3rat who manipulates Max to do what she wants. The only reason why Max chooses to be Chloe's punching bag is due to guilt of not staying in touch. 

There are a lot of questions that are not answered. Why does the storm arrive. Why did God/mother nature give Max powers and why did they try this experiment with Max and Chloe? Why can't Dontnud make a competent game? Why do so many people think Chloe's an Maxs' relationship is "cute" despite it clearly being a toxic one. 

This game depresses me, it shouldn't exist, 
But there is money to be made from middle aged millennials with poor money management skills and too much free time, and by elder gen Z who steal money from their parents' purse. 
It preys on people who have poor taste and who can't shoot for shit… but who still want to spend 30-60$ on a game to escape from the real world because its not special enough for them. 

Devs tried their best to manipulate people who suffered topics that are in life is strange to make them believe the game has quality. It works well with given music. 

If this game holds a special place in your life because "representation" you need to re-evaluate your choices and stop being a weakling who needs "representation" to feel strong.

145390493.review: Life is Strange definitely gets you invested in its story the more you go in. There's interesting characters (for one you get to play as an ex-pirate but now a ninja witch, that pulls Barry Allens) that aren't just good or bad, and give you mixed you mixed feelings, which in turn make the choices harder to make, as there's not always a winning situation. The magic mechanic is pretty fun, as one of the first things I did was replay a football hitting someone 5-6 times before I warned them about it. Be warned, however, the game will be gaslighting you every chance it gets - you'll make a choice then the game will be like "Maybe I shouldn't have done that" then you rewind and make the other choice and game will be like "Maybe I should've done something". Also quite enjoyed the bits that start making you question if things are real or if you're losing your mind at this point (mainly from pulling Barry Allens). And finally, I did love the story, but to be fair found the endings kind of disappointing, mainly because both of them felt like they devoid all of your choices throughout the game of meaning, as in you could've saved everyone or been as evil as possible but in the end all of those actions are either erased or annihilated.

I was late to this game, but I finally got through the storm. I didn't really know much going into the game, other than the two girls, and this was the type of game where choices matter. By the end of the first episode I knew I had to play till the end. Each new episode I finished through left me with my mouth open. It just kept getting bigger and bigger.

Without giving spoilers, I will have to say the very last episode was just a little less fun for me. Lets just say it got crazier and crazier. The first half was fine, it was the second half that was starting to lose me. Out of the last choices, I thought for sure that I would end up having to choose between letting Max sacrifice herself in Chloe's place. It wasn't that big. It was just a simple either or. Was still kind of sad.

If you haven't played this yet and/or had your eye on it, I would recommend it. I waited and had a blast with this. I plan to play the others in the franchise.

[b]Negatives[/b]:
[list]

[/list]

144675905.review:
Life is Strange quickly became my favourite game for many reasons. The game is more than just its gameplay; it’s an emotional ride that sticks with you long after you’ve finished playing.

I really enjoyed the unique twist with Max’s time-reversal ability. It makes the choices you make feel important and adds a nice touch to the gameplay, making you think twice before making a decision. The replayability is a bonus too, you can go back and see how different choices affect the story​​.

The characters are what make this game special. They start off as typical archetypes but as the story progresses, they become more complex and relatable. It’s the character development that really hooked me in and kept me playing​​.

The setting in Arcadia Bay is calming but the issues the characters face are anything but. The game does a great job of tackling real-world issues that young adults and teens face, making it not just a game, but an experience that makes you think​​.

The emotional impact of the story is something I wasn’t expecting but greatly appreciated. You get invested in Max’s life and the challenges she faces. The ending really hit hard and left me thinking about it for days​​.

In a nutshell, Life is Strange is a beautifully crafted game that takes you on an emotional journey through a well-told story filled with interesting characters and a unique gameplay mechanic. I’d recommend it to anyone looking for a game with a deep, engaging story.

But I'd be lying if I said the dialogue doesn't get better, because it does. On the other hand we have the gameplay which isn't hald bad! The puzzles aren't too hard and they're a nice addition (even though they can be bothersome and annoying later on in the story). Aside from that we have the soundtrack which is mesmerizing! If you get through the awkward writing of episode one, you'll get to experience a wonderful and complex story that has made me (and my friends whom i forced to play) cry several times. This game is a modern classic and I wholeheartedly recommend it!
Side note: I don't have much playtme on Steam since I played on the ps4, still, I wanted to leave a review of one of my favorite games ever.

144217810.review:
I haven't even finished this game yet - as of writing, I am on Episode 4's beginning. But, I just... have to talk about this game, no - experience.

To start off, I want to sort of... explain my perspective. I remember seeing this game when it was releasing the episodes over time on console. I still had a 360 at the time, and given how I was... 13 or so, I didn't pay much attention. I kinda regret that now, to be honest.

Everything, from the music, to the characters, to the environment - all of it encapsulates the experience the developers wanted you to have - it impacts your emotions in the direction they wanted it to(which in a lot of cases, is depressing), and it's a beautiful work of storytelling. Seeing the development of Max and Chloe's relationship is such an amazing, almost... surreal experience. I think people can draw their own parallels from their own lives to these characters, and that alone is something beautiful.

Words possess power and strength beyond what one could know, in many ways. It's fitting enough to say that on a game where your choices do matter - where your actions and sayings have a direct effect on your relationships, on the very world around you. At a point, it transcends beyond what you would call a game, and feels more akin to a novel, a good piece of literature - a true masterpiece in its own right, that as we have seen, is standing the test of time well.

Plus, you know a game's good when you can say so many positive things in a review, and not even have finished it yet. 10/10 so far, I highly recommend, sale or not. I don't think it's gonna change from a 10/10 either. :)

Edit: Finished the game, got all the achievements. Episode 5 was a total mindfuck, and threw me off guard in a lot of ways I won't spoil here. Game also made me depressed at certain points, and even had me tear up and cry a little. Still a 10/10. Will most likely come back to this in the near future for another playthrough.

143709244.review:
I'm very late to playing this game considering its release date, but I once promised myself I would get around to it because I've always loved episodic "your-choice-matters" games, and needless to say my only regret is not playing it sooner.

Without even mentioning the story, I think the game offers a really pretty art style and it has a lot of funny language that expresses its timeframe so well. The characters are all diverse and well thought out, as is the rest of the story, dialogue, and choices - they feel like real, unique people with their own quirks. This connection you build with the cast accentuates every moment and tragedy this masterful story puts on the table. The game is perfectly capable of making the player laugh, cry, and even build resentment toward its characters. I believe the game has not one message or takeaway to be had, but instead, many. Maybe the most obvious theme is to cherish every moment and person, because, unlike Max Caulfield, the average person cannot time travel or take photos to literally relive memories. The consequence of her abilities is the skillfully conveyed guilt that she experiences for her actions, and each moment of hopelessness and pain creeps up on the player just as much. Overall its a very beautiful story that, pardon me, made me cry like a bitch several times, and I would recommend it to anyone who enjoys this style of game.

143620313.review:
spoiler alert
The game was great, but I wish it didn't shy away from strengthening the bond you have with the established main characters, you as a reader didn't get enough time to get invested in any of the characters, so it didn't matter when it came time to make important choices. The rewind ability is interesting in theory, but in reality it simply invalidates any dilemma Max had to encounter. 

For example, when you're in Chloe's house in episode 4, even though the episode is entirely about her and the dilemma you went through to change her past, you don't really spend any time with her, when she asks you to  get her water, you simply investigate her room, and then get rewarded with a 30 second cutscene where you watch a movie with her. 
The next morning, you spend all your time, talking with her parents and probing around her house, NOT SPENDING TIME WITH CHLOE. Do you see the problem?

Perhaps my expectations were too high going into this, but Life is Strange.

143225794.review:
Novela visual de ciencia ficción en 5 capítulos, la trama es sobre una pseudo heroína con un poder relacionado con la “teoría del caos” enunciada por James Yorke que nos recuerda que “El mundo no sigue un principio milimétrico y predecible”. 

La historia la protagoniza la adolescente Max Caufield, de quien sabremos sobre su personalidad, con quienes se relaciona, de como es su vida estudiantil, íntima y familiar.

Se juega utilizando unos árboles de diálogos cuando “Max” se enfrenta a situaciones que requieren una conversación, un comentario o toma de decisiones que son escogidas por el jugador, estas decisiones afectarán los resultados en el desarrollo de la historia y su final.

El juego es recomendable para jóvenes por la pertinencia y actualidad de sus temáticas referentes al acoso escolar,  problemáticas familiares y cotidianas.

El primer capitulo es gratuito, por lo que recomiendo comprar los 4 restantes a través del bundle durante las rebajas.

143216857.review:
Life is Strange touts itself as an episodic adventure game that allows the player to rewind time and affect the past, present and future. In fact the loading screen before every one of the five episodes in the game, hammers it through that your choices have consequences, your choices matter. 

But for the most part these choices, which the time manipulation rewind effect does let you affect, are minutia and largely inconsequential events. Events such as someone getting a ball thrown after them. On top of that it has no cost to use the powers, either in game mechanics sense or in the overall plot sense. 

For the most of the events that can be manipulated, they have little impact on the overarching story, outside of a few critical moments that must be resolved, correctly, to see the story continue.

This lack of cost stands in stark contrast to what the main character says early on in the game, where she states she shouldn't use her powers frivolously, but even if you ignore that statement and go ham with her powers at every possible moment, it has no effect on the story, which is kinda silly given the core plot focuses around precisely her use of her powers and the large consequences using them appear to have, but that seemingly only matters when it comes to Chloe.

So despite repeated statements that consequences matter, there is only one choice that matters as the ending presents itself as a binary choice, A or B, and nothing leading up to that moment, from the players actions, makes any difference.

This leads to the point that there really isn't much of any gameplay to speak of here, it's an interactive Young Adult novel that plays out over five episodes, much like a TV series. Which isn't necessarily a negative point, but like most Young Adult entertainment these days, it falls to the same tropes seen elsewhere, such as including characters acting out of character to service the plot and storytelling, and when it finally comes down to the conclusion, the writers cannot weave together their various plot points and plot elements they've spent five episodes leading up to so it all ends up being nonsensical in the end.

The voice acting is decent and the musical score feels contemporary for this portrayed small town setting the game takes place in. The graphics range from serviceable to leaving a lot to be desired at times and doesn't feel very consistent in its presentation.

So while Life is Strange isn't inherently terrible, or even a bad game, it also isn't overwhelmingly positive, as the Steam reviews would suggest. The game has 161.317 reviews at the time of writing, of which only around 20% has 10+ hours of playtime, in a game with roughly 15 hours of playtime or longer, depending on the level of completion employed. The final achievement in the game also shows only around 25% even completed it. Which paints a very different picture to the very positive reception it seems to have enjoyed. Perhaps it's even a bit misleading.

So just like the games binary ending, the review much also be binary, positive or negative, and thus it falls towards negative.

143134418.review:
Esto sera largo

Antes consideraba a los juegos de elecciones sosos y tibios, no sentía que mis elecciones influían en los personajes. Pero este juego me demostró lo contrario.
Life is Strange es un juego que no es para todos, es tranquilo, pero no aburrido. 

Los problemas que muestran en la historia son realmente fuertes. Las actuaciones de voz dan vida a personajes bien desarrollados. Realmente me siento mal al decirles o hacerles cosas a otros personajes. 
El apartado visual es hermoso, demuestra que no se necesitan gráficos ultra realistas para una buena inmersión, solo con una buena historia basto. 
El sonido esta muy bien trabajado, la música te ayuda a sentirte dentro de ese mundo y te deja sentir las emociones. 

Es un juego que acabo de terminar, y creo que no volveré a sentir los sentimientos que se cruzaban por mi cabeza mientras lo jugaba. Estoy seguro que esa sensación extraña, parecida a una nostalgia agradable, es fruto de la ambientación que ofrece el juego. Hay que re-jugarlo unas 3 veces: La primera tenes que ser vos y tomar tus decisiones, la segunda y tercera para explorar las otras. A decir verdad no pensé que me gustara tanto, le tenia fe pero fue mas que eso. 
La historia junto a los diálogos son perfectos para reflexionar muchísimo sobre ciertos temas, como el paso del tiempo, los abusos, la capacidad de las personas.
Si tenes corazón lagrimeas con el final, pero podes llorar mucho.

Simplemente, cine.

142877089.review:
This series has 4/5 good episodes, those being the first 4. They are very well paced, have interesting story, characters, dialog, and choices for you to make along the way. I genuinely enjoyed the first 4 episodes and was anticipating each new one as it came out.

Episode 5 botched all of that, somehow. The pacing is weird after the first half, the story falls apart, the time travel mechanic gets a funky twist that isn't very fun, and your choices in this and all previous episodes get thrown out the window for a 2 button option Deus Ex ending that makes the first 4 episodes basically pointless. It was such a disappointment especially after waiting for it to come out and streaming it for friends the day it dropped. Can't recommend it unless you're fine just playing the first 4 episodes and ending on a major cliffhanger.

142793778.review:
[h1] Mild spoilers ahead [/h1]

A year ago, I interviewed an opera director who told me that people won't always be in your life forever: "Like the fairy godmother, they can come, change your life like magic, sprinkle a bit of pixie dust and disappear." We want to hold onto them forever, clutch them tightly, but sometimes we have to let go and learn to live without them. 

Life is Strange is, at its core, about losing people. It's about accepting loss and coping with grief, in all of its messy and painful ways. The story revolves around teenager Max Caulfield, a timid and anxious girl who witnesses a long-lost childhood friend being murdered whilst at school. In that split second, Max discovers that she can reverse time and change the outcome of situations using an intense emotional reaction.

Across five episodes, Max uses her powers to prevent the deaths of several key characters. From a suicidal student, bullied for being drugged and made to commit sexual acts, and preventing the death of her closest friend's family member in a car crash. When we lose someone we love, we can feel overwhelmingly guilty that we could have done something to change the outcome. Due to Max's obsession with perfecting the universe, she inadvertently twists reality into a nightmarish dreamscape infinitely worse than if she had left everything alone. Upon facing this, Max has to make one final decision. 

A significant portion of my 20s has been spent trying to navigate loss and, more specifically, guilt. I've dedicated years to trying to reassess what I could have done differently; I've felt consumed by a bitter sense of guilt which begs me to find a fixable flaw in my personality to stop this from happening again. It's a testament to Life is Strange that, upon the game's conclusion, years of pain escaped by body through tears which flooded down my cheeks. I held onto the person next to me so tightly, squeezing them as I let out years of pain onto their shoulder.

Looking back, it reminds me of that interview with the Opera director. People will enter our lives, change us forever, and they'll leave. Like side characters, or fairy godmothers, they can teach us so much about ourselves, help us find the beauty in ourselves, but eventually every curtain has to close. We can rewind these stories in our heads, permanently pondering what we could have done differently, but Life is Strange helped teach me how to move forward.

Thank you, Life is Strange, for helping me explore my own personal healing through one of the most compelling, beautiful and emotionally intense games I've ever played.

142078718.review:
It feels criminal to have taken this long after release for me to try one of the most critically-acclaimed story games, but Life is Strange truly lives up to its reputation. It is extremely impressive what they managed to pull off with the resources they had at the time, and the cast of characters brilliantly brought to life by the performances of the voice actors.

I applaud the handling of the many mature themes depicted in the game, which is not something easily done in a manner that's both respectful and helps raise awareness.

The lack of facial motion capture (which is one of the only things the remastered improved on) and some awkwardly-written dialogue are all of the few negative points I can think of this game.

Like some people, I do feel that Chloe as a character has little redeeming qualities, and makes little sense for Max to put up with her antics throughout the game. But, then again, the world is a vast place; not everyone agrees on the same things, and it's very possible there are quite a few people that find her likeable.

142047514.review: This is the best story game I have ever played, and it has rightfully earned the title of my current favorite game. I am a fan of choice games, but none of the ones I have played have delivered such a great story that I have gotten so completely absorbed in to this degree. I started the game having no idea what to expect (I had only heard of it, saw it had good reviews, and saw it was on sale and cheap, so why not), but I will be honest and say that after I had played chapter one and was halfway through chapter two, I did not have high hopes for the rest of the game. I didn't hate it, but I wasn't really into it, so I stopped playing and forgot about it until I was bored a couple weeks later. Then I made it to near the end of chapter two, picked some dialogue options I can now definitely say were the wrong choices, and was totally hooked on the game. And it only got so much better from that point on. This is one of the best games I think I will ever play, if you haven't played it yet, you are missing out.

The writing is cheesy, but the characters act like teenagers just being goofballs instead of like a Hollywood movie where like there'd be a lot of sex jokes and maybe even a scene. 141959746.review:
Life is strange es un juego que recomiendo a todo el mundo, gráficamente es hermoso, la banda sonora es tan buena que tengo una playlist con todas sus canciones. El guion y desarrollo es destacable, pero el verdadero punto fuerte de este juego son los personajes.

Los personajes secundarios son muy interesantes, cada acción tiene su trasfondo y sus consecuencias. Realmente son personajes super profundos e incluso uno como jugador se interesa honestamente en su historia y las cosas que cada uno de ellos tiene para contar. Creo que mi personaje secundario favorito es Warren porque es muy tierno y lo amo <3 sinceramente me quede con ganas de saber más de el y de su vida.

Otro de mis personajes favoritos es mi novia Chloe Price, creo que Chloe es un personaje que cualquier jugador te LIS ama. Es hermosa, es lo que las manic pixie dream girl wanna be quieren ser.

 La protagonista Max, es una protagonista super presente en el sentido de que no se siente que al estar  jugando uno este vaciamente controlando la vida de Max y tomando decisiones por ella, cada decisión disponible es honesta y consecuente  a su personalidad, pero teniendo en cuenta que tampoco tiene una personalidad lo suficientemente fuerte o destacable para llegar a ser irritante o poco empatizable, Max me parece un sano punto medio, personalmente es un personaje con el que genere mucha empatia, y realmente pude sentir tensión, nervios e incluso miedo a pesar de que obviamente la jugabilidad no es el fuerte de este juego, si no su historia, lo cual me lleva al siguiente tema;

Me encanta pensar en los videojuegos como un método de llevar la cinematografía un poco mas allá. Los videojuegos son un medio muy maleable e inmersivo, ya que es uno mismo el que lleva la historia y no es la historia la que lo lleva a uno. Muchas personas no le dan una oportunidad a juegos como estos porque no tienen una buena jugabilidad. Y es verdad, Life is Strange y en general cualquier juego de la categoría "las decisiones importan" no van a tener una buena jugabilidad, su enfoque tiene que ser otro. Hay que darle una oportunidad a esta clase de juegos porque los videojuegos son mucho más que mecánicas y jugabilidad. Muchas veces un juego con una buena historia es mucho mejor que uno sin ella pero con mecánicas increíbles.

si hay una sola cosa mala de este juego esa es que me dejo un hueco en el corazón una vez lo termine. Igualmente yo lo veo super rejugable, algun dia voy a jugarlo nuevamente para sacar todas las imagenes del juego ;)

En fin:

Lo recomiendo? Si
Es un juegazo? Si
Chloe me hizo lesbiana? No, ya lo era desde antes

141958201.review:
Life is Strange is a game that left an indelible mark on my heart. From the moment I started playing, I was immediately drawn into its captivating story, which delves into the complexities of human struggles. The narrative and characters dialogue feels incredibly realistic, exploring themes of friendship and love in a way that resonated deeply with me. I became fully invested in the lives of Max and Chloe, empathizing with their triumphs and feeling their pain. The emotional rollercoaster I experienced throughout the game was a testament to its powerful storytelling and the ability to evoke genuine emotions.

But it wasn't just the story that moved me; it was the impeccable soundtrack that amplified those emotions to another level. The carefully curated songs and original score were perfectly timed and placed, adding an extra layer of depth and intensity to each scene. I remember how I dig into spotify to find every song of this game to enjoy it in real life.

Life is Strange was more than just a game for me; it was a personal journey of self-reflection. It reminded me of the beauty and struggles of being human, and it left a lasting impression on my soul. The captivating story and the evocative soundtrack worked hand in hand to create an experience that was both thought-provoking and emotionally resonant. It's a game that I will forever cherish as a testament to the power of storytelling and the ability of video games to touch our hearts in profound ways.

Regardless, the aesthetic of the world and details allow the environments to feel realistic and attached, combining elements of sketches, photography, and watercolor as examples. The graphics have aged somewhat roughly, along with some of its optimization. Overall, though, this game takes the player on an adventure that offers thought-provoking weight, an ekphrasis of people and places.

141810419.review:
Life is strange is a story about a young woman named Max, who can control time and change it. Max soon realizes that messing with time doesn’t always make things better. In fact it can make it a lot worse.

The story is decent but is filled with a lot of cringy dialogue at times. A lot of the story focuses on your friend Chloe who is a rebellious teenager who is always angry at the world, and often uses heavy guilt tripping on her friend Max to get her way. 
While the story has a lot of choices the player can choose, the final outcome to the game remains the same. It is still entertaining to see the various choices play out and then rewind time to see what else could have happened. The choices you make do slightly shape the story so it feels like it did have an impact.

The gameplay is more of a walking simulator with some very light puzzle solving such as obtaining an item, rewinding time, and then use that item.
Rewinding time mid conversation to use any information obtained is also part of puzzle solving you will come across. You can also use your camera to take pictures throughout the game tho they are more like collectibles rather than a core mechanic.

The graphics still look very decent and the voice acting is extremely good. The game has a nice looking art style to it and the animations are fluid and look decent enough where there’s no stiff or janky movements.

Overall a decent game with a story that is original, even if a bit cringy at times.

8/10

141644507.review:
Spoilers ahead, be warned.

This game has a funny effect on how you think about your own past right after a longer session. It's classic. There's problems like certain slightly annoying parts that branch a lot and also rewind slowly or rewinding other events completely unrelated to what you're focusing on on accident. The story isn't as big a whop as I've heard it to be but it isn't horrible, tho it is using teenage dumbness as a plot crutch a lot. Most of the dialog options you get to pick out of are accurate to what you will actually say but there isn't a whole lot of options so I frequently encountered situations in which none of the dialog options seemed fitting.

I'd give it a neutral review, but rewinding certain satisfying parts was fun so..

Life is Strange is the best game ever because it's the only game where you can [spoiler]kill Chloe Price.[/spoiler]

Jokes aside, I actually enjoyed the story even though it feels like it's catering to a very specific demographic of person. I find the main love interest in this game very dislikable and manipulative and I wish she was more like Stella, Brooke or Kate, who are all super charming and sweet in their own ways.

The mystery aspect of the game is the fun part, and it does feel satisfying to put together the pieces and figure out what is going on in Arcadia Bay. The last episode however, is too abstract, too grandiose and makes all of your detective work feel pointless.

Also, this is an easy game to 100% if you're up for it.

141397595.review:
What an amazing game.  While it came out 8 years ago, I only just played it for the first time.  I had not watched or read anything about this prior to playing, and what an experience it was!  I did not play the remastered collection, so some of my thoughts may be moot with the remaster.  At times I found the lack of lip movement when the characters were speaking to be a bit distracting.  The use of terminology and slang like "hella" and "apropos" got to a point by the third episode where I audibly laughed and rolled my eyes, which took away from the immersion.  But, on the whole, those things really don't matter.  This story is beautiful and heartbreaking.  The score is phenomenal.  The characters are fleshed out so thoroughly that you really feel for people and think about them and their situation long after you have shut down the game and tried - key word TRIED - to go to sleep.  But you can't, because you are still thinking about this game.  When it was all coming to a head in the final moments of the game, I was left deep in my feelings (which this game will most certainly do to you).

If you have not played this one, I absolutely recommend you give it a try.  It is a masterpiece.  Be aware of potential trigger warnings for such things as unaliving, drug use, assault, etc.  There are moments that are heartbreaking and difficult.  Take care of yourself.

141395618.review:
Life is Strange is an interesting game. I wouldn't say it's great or even that good, but it's interesting. The rewind mechanic is fun to toy around with and use to get through obstacles, learn knowledge in the future and use in the past, etc. That mechanic and using it is probably the most interesting part of the game. A lot of people criticize the characters and the way they talk, but I think it's intentionally "campy" / silly and it's best to simply not try and take it too seriously. The most questionable part of the game is the final choice, where you get to choose between either a fitting ending that perfectly closes out the story, OR... an ending so jarring that it'd be the equivalent of Oppenheimer being giddy with delight after calling himself death, the destroyer of worlds. 

I lightly recommend this game.

141321421.review:
I like Life is Strange overall despite its many problems.

The puppet animations are distracting. It does have some really bad "hip" dialogue. It does feel like a growing-up story and this detective story were put right next to each other, and they don't necessarily mesh well together. And I was replaying it, the motivation to continue playing wasn't as strong as the first time.

The time-rewinding powers have mixed results. They did try to implement in puzzles, and it means that any time pressure for a certain scene is taken off, and you can see the short-term consequences. I also like that you can also fast-forward if you've seen an option. But it also seems arbitrary that it's tied to scenes and not actual time passed. The solution in puzzles are nearly always the same. And the time-travel powers are bent to the need of the narrative.

I like the Max-Chloe relationship and the town of Arcadia Bay is interesting enough. I find the voice acting generally strong. I also really like the game thematically, it's a "choices" game where that idea is criticised. Now I actually don't think that was purposeful considering that the same directors and writers also helmed Life is Strange 2 where that idea is taken seriously. I like the music too.

140978506.review:
One of the most—if not THE most—powerful narrative experiences I have ever went trough. It made me tear up more than once and gets more powerful the further in the story you get.
The story starts somewhat nice (with a fistful of salt), then becomes seriously messed up, penultimately gets really trippy, and culminates with a bittersweet end. I couldn't sleep as the mind was racing when I finished around 2.30am.

Some choices are between good and bad, some between bad and worse, and some choices are plain shitty no matter from what angle you look at it (just in a different way), but it's that courage to not give arbitrary escape hatch that is giving it such strength.
The gameplay is bare-bones mild explore, interact, talk, choose, and rewind to choose differently either out of necessity or desire, but it's clear the most of work went into building the story and to its benefit; so much so I got lost a bit in the complexity.

The one thing that is a bit immersion breaking is the lip-sync—or lack thereof. It's not far off the characters just flapping their lower jaw up and down while talking, no matter what they are saying and how. I understand it's a huge amount of work and gets expensive, so I don't hold it against it. The voice acting is still excellent though.

140923541.review:
I really enjoyed the overall storytelling and art style of this game. I did at times feel that the game sort of dragged but that could be that I felt compelled to explore and interact with the objects in the world to collect the photos (which I failed at). 

The last chapter which had a sequences that were confusing and a pain to figure out, I had to resort to using online guides for one of them. I didn't find that sequence necessary and the placement of at least one character in it didn't necessarily fit the story based on the options that players had. 

My biggest criticism would be while the game claims that players decisions matter, they don't actually matter during the most important part, the ending. What options you decided to take during the game doesn't matter at all. No matter what you choose, you will have all options available to you regarding the ending. This was a let down for me because I was hoping that my decisions would be important for end game. The developers decision to allow players to decide how to end the game no matter what they decided during the previous four chapters diminished the impact of the ending imo.

The visuals are kind of a minus for me. They look outdated even for 2015. Art direction masks that though and the game is otherwise very enjoyable. So basically a really good interactive story about life with supernatural elements.

140648772.review:
Maxine Caulfield es una amante de la fotografía que descubre una habilidad extraordinaria para retroceder en el tiempo. Esta capacidad le brinda la oportunidad de cambiar cualquier situación y tomar decisiones diferentes. Si se equivoca en una respuesta a una pregunta, simplemente retrocede. Si rompe o toma algo que pertenece a otra persona, puede revertirlo. Max utiliza este don para ayudarse a sí misma y a los demás, aunque las consecuencias de sus acciones son impredecibles. El rebobinado del tiempo se convierte en la característica principal de Life Is Strange, donde Max se enfrenta a obstáculos, mentiras, apoyo, así como secretos y misterios por descubrir.

Life Is Strange comparte similitudes con Remember Me y los productos de Telltale Games. El juego te permite explorar diversos lugares y interactuar con los personajes. Cada personaje es único a su manera, y tienes la oportunidad de tomar decisiones que influirán en el curso de los acontecimientos. La atmósfera del juego se captura de manera excepcional, haciendo que te sientas personalmente involucrado en la historia. Los gráficos son hermosos y los personajes se vuelven entrañables. Tu actitud hacia ellos puede cambiar a lo largo del juego, y algunos revelarán sorprendentes secretos que no esperabas. La banda sonora complementa perfectamente la atmósfera a lo largo de los cinco episodios.

La trama de Life Is Strange es emocionante y llena de sorpresas. Es imposible predecir qué sucederá a continuación, aunque a veces puedas hacer conjeturas que se cumplen en cierta medida. Hay giros y vueltas inesperados, y tomar decisiones importantes y difíciles es fundamental en el juego. Lo más destacado son los dos finales completamente diferentes que no están relacionados entre sí. Ambos finales son conmovedores y tristes, aunque esperaba un poco más de ellos. A pesar de los finales, la sensación general es de tristeza porque el juego ha llegado a su fin. Es como terminar de leer un libro interesante y no querer que acabe. 

Un gran reconocimiento para Dontnod Entertainment por su excelente trabajo. Han logrado crear una experiencia de juego que no se queda atrás en comparación con los juegos de Telltale Games. Life Is Strange es un juego maravilloso que recomiendo comprar. Merece una calificación perfecta de 10 sobre 10.
